Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION#1:
On August 7, 2020, Resident A’s finger was broken when Resident B physically
attacked him. Resident A’s foster care worker was never notified about the incident until
August 12, 2020. To date, Mott Children’s Residence has not provided any safety plan
or documentation stating how Resident A and Resident B will be separated moving
forward. It is unclear where staff was during this incident as well.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed MDHHS Foster Care Worker 1 via telephone on August 20, 2020. She
stated on August 7, 2020 Resident A had legos inside of a blanket that belonged to
another peer. A different peer took the blanket from Resident A making the legos scatter
everywhere. Resident A got upset and cussed while cleaning up his legos. Resident A
was then threatened by a peer who attacked him once support staff exited the unit.
Resident A was punched in the face several times and kicked. He was immediately
taken to the medical staff, where he received an icepack for his hand. Foster Care
Worker 1 reported on August 11, 2020, Resident A stated he wanted to press charges
on the peer, due to being bullied and due to the peer breaking his finger. She stated
she was never notified about the incident on August 7, 2020, which resulted in Resident
A’s finger being broken, until the email was sent on August 12, 2020 stating Resident A
wanted to press charges. She said she was just informed that Resident A will be moving
to another Whaley Children’s Center residential facility so Resident A will be separated
from the peer that attacked him.
I interviewed Resident A face-to-face on-site on August 26, 2020. Resident A said he
was on Vemco unit sitting on the bench with legos that were inside a blanket. Resident
B tried to grab the blanket and when he did the legos fell on the floor. He said Resident
B then started hitting him and staff (he could not recall the staff's name) pulled Resident
B off of him. He said he does not know why Resident B started hitting him. He said he
went to the hospital because his finger was hurting. They gave him an ice pack and
then he had to go to another place on a different day to get x-rays. He said that the
hospital said his finger was not broken. He said after he left the hospital, the hospital
said that his finger was broken and he got a cast on his finger. He said that his finger
feels better now and that it is healing.
I interviewed Mott Children's Residence Staff 1 face-to-face on-site on August 26, 2020.
Staff 1 reported Resident A had been antagonizing the other resident. He had been
redirected to stop. Resident A had legos inside a blanket and he was sitting on the
bench inside the unit because they were getting ready to leave the unit. Resident B
grabbed the blanket and the legos fell on the floor. Resident A started cursing. While
she was helping Resident A pick up the legos off of the floor, Resident B started hitting
Resident A. She stated she immediately pulled Resident B away. Staff 1 reported staff f
kept Resident A and Resident B away from each other for the rest of the night. She
reported Resident A was placed at another Whaley Children’s Center house after the
incident.
3

I interviewed Mott Children's Residence Staff 3 face-to-face on-site on August 26, 2020.
Staff 3 said Resident A was taken to the hospital on August 7, 2020 and Mott Children’s
Residence was told Resident A’s finger was not broken. Resident A had x-rays taken
later that day. She stated the hospital called Mott Children’s Residence on August 10,
2020 and indicated that Resident A’s finger was fractured. Mott Children’s Residence
Staff 6 emailed DCWL Consultant 1 regarding the injury. She stated the hospital faxed
medical documentation to Mott Children’s Residence on August 11, 2020. Mott
Children’s Residence emailed MDHHS Foster Care Worker 1 on August 11, 2020 once
they were informed of the finger fracture.
I reviewed medical documents on August 26, 2020. The nursing notes documented the
following:
 August 7, 2020 at 3:31 p.m. – Resident A was seen by nurse for finger and taken
to Mott Children’s Hospital. There were no abnormal findings. The range of
motion (ROM) was within normal limits but Resident A is having pain in area. Ice
applied and Motrin given. The doctor ordered x-rays just to be sure there was no
fracture in the area. Resident A’s nose was bleeding, ice applied to that area as
well. Bleeding stopped after 15 mins.
 August 10, 2020 - Staff took Resident A to Michigan Ortho where they applied a
finger splint to his left hand for broken ring finger. Resident A must wear it for 7-
10 days and has an appointment on August 21, 2020.
 August 11, 2020 - A message was left for the nurse from Hurley Hospital
indicating that Resident A’s finger was fractured and he needed to be followed up
by Michigan Ortho.
 August 25, 2020-Resident A went to get splint removed at Michigan Ortho. Splint
was removed and a manual splint with medical tape and fracture is healing well.
Keep two fingers taped together until next appointment on September 11, 2020.
I reviewed an email dated August 10, 2020 at 3:32 p.m. sent by Staff 6 to DCWL
Consultant 1. The email stated Resident A’s finger was broken in an altercation with a
peer. This occurred on August 7, 2020. He was taken to Hurley ER for x-ray’s on
August 7, 2020 and they were informed it was not broken. However, they received a
call on August 10, 2020 from Resident A’s pediatrician’s office indicating that it was
broken. Resident A was at Ortho Michigan for further treatment.
I reviewed an email dated August 11, 2020 from Mott Children’s Residence to MDHHS
Foster Care Worker 1. Resident A’s medical paperwork from Hurley Hospital was sent
to MDHHS Foster Care Worker 1. The medical document stated Resident A was
examined on August 7, 2020 for pain. He was diagnosed with a nondisplaced fracture
involving distal portion of proximal phalanx of left fourth finger with intra-articular
extension within proximal interphalangeal joint. There was minimal soft tissue swelling.
On August 26, 2020, I reviewed an incident report dated August 7, 2020 and completed
by Staff 1. The incident report stated Resident A had ben redirected earlier in the shift to
stop antagonizing peers and he stopped. After breakfast, Resident A and his peers sat
4

on the readiness bench while waiting to go to the family game room. Resident A had
legos inside a blanket belonging to another peer. A different peer snatched the blanket
from Resident A, making the legos fall on the floor. Resident A became upset and
cursed while cleaning his legos up and was threatened by a peer, who then attacked
him once support staff had exited the unit. Resident A was punched in the face several
times as well as kicked. Resident A was immediately taken to medical staff where he
received an icepack for his hand.
I interviewed Mott Children's Residence Staff 5 via telephone on August 27, 2020. Staff
5 stated she was not on the unit when the altercation between Resident A and Resident
B occurred. She reported she had only seen the legos on the floor. She said she was on
a 1:1 with another youth. That youth had breakfast and staff wanted him to shower but
he wanted to call his mother first. He started to walk off the unit so she followed him.
Staff 5 stated when returned to the unit, less than five minutes later, Resident A and
Resident B were calm. She reported Resident A and Resident B were separated for the
rest of the day and night.
I interviewed Mott Children's Residence Staff 3 via telephone on September 17, 2020.
Staff 3 reported a message was left for Resident A’s father on August 12, 2020
regarding the injury to Resident A’s finger. She stated Resident A’s father did not return
the phone call.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to show that Mott Children’s
Residence failed to provide appropriate supervision for Resident
A and an appropriate safety plan following the incident between
Resident A and Resident B. Staff 1 was present during the
incident and immediately separated Resident A and Resident B
when Resident B began hitting Resident A. Resident A and
Resident B were kept separate for the remainder of the day and
night. Resident A was moved to Optimist House after the
incident occurred as part of the safety plan.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4150 Incident reporting.
(1) Any incident resulting in serious injury of a resident or
illness requiring inpatient hospitalization, shall be reported
to the parent/ legal guardian, responsible referring agency,
and the licensing authority as soon as possible, but not
more than 24 hours after the incident.
ANALYSIS: There is sufficient evidence to show that Mott Children’s
Residence did not notify Resident A’s parents not more than 24
hours after they were informed by Hurley Hospital that Resident
A’s finger was fractured. Hurley Hospital called Mott Children’s
Residence on August 10, 2020 and a message was left for
Resident A’s father on August 12, 2020.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION#2:
On August 12, 2020, Resident A had something under his arm in which was a female
peer's underwear he had taken from a cubby. He explained he took them so he could
put them on in the shower because it made him feel like he was having kids with the
female peer. It was unknown how Resident A had access to this female peer's cubby
and where supervision was during the time, he was able to take the underwear.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed MDHHS Foster Care Worker 1 via telephone on August 20, 2020. She
reported on August 18, 2020 she was notified on August 12, 2020 that Mott Children’s
Residence staff noted Resident A had something under his arm in which was a female
peer's underwear he had taken from a cubby. He explained he took them so he could
put them on in the shower because it made him feel like he was having kids with the
female peer. MDHHS Foster Care Worker 1 stated she does not know how Resident A
had access to this female peer's cubby and she does not know where staff was during
the time, he was able to take the underwear.
I interviewed Resident A face-to-face on-site on August 26, 2020. Resident A denied
taking anything belonging to his peers, including underwear from another resident's
cubby which is located by the readiness bench.
I interviewed Mott Children's Residence Staff 2 face-to-face on-site on August 26, 2020.
Staff 2 said the residents were on the unit sitting on the bench as they just came inside
the unit. She reported the female resident had clothes in her cubby that she must have
forgotten to put away. She said sometimes the female resident likes to put her clothes in
the cubby when she gets ready for her shower. Resident A asked Staff 2 if she could let
6

him into his room because he needed to put his shoes up. She said Resident A had his
arm down and she saw something under his arm. She asked him what it was and he
said he did not have anything. Staff 2 reported Mott Children’s Residence Staff 4 came
onto the unit and Resident A lifted up his arm and the female resident’s underwear fell
on the floor. She stated Staff 4 talked to Resident A about the incident. Staff 2 stated
that the female peer is no longer allowed to keep any clothes in the cubby.
I interviewed Mott Children's Residence Staff 4 face-to-face on-site on August 26, 2020.
Staff 4 stated when he walked onto the unit, Resident A had something tucked under
his arm. Staff 4 asked Resident A to show him what was under his arm. Resident A
lifted his arm and the underwear fell to the floor. He reported that he then discussed the
incident with Resident A. Staff 4 thinks Resident A took the underwear whenever he
was sitting on the readiness bench and the female resident had clothes in her cubby,
which is located right above the bench. Staff 4 reported that the female peer is no
longer allowed to keep any clothes in the cubby.
On August 26, 2020, I reviewed an incident report dated August 12, 2020 and
completed by Staff 2. The incident report stated Resident A was sitting on the bench
waiting to get moved in. Resident A then asked her if she could open his room so that
he could grab something. As staff was walking to Resident A’s room, she noticed
Resident A put something under his arm to hide it. When she stopped Resident A to
ask him what it was, Resident A refused to show her. When Resident A finally agreed
to show staff, he revealed he had a pair of underwear taken from his female peer’s
cubby. When staff asked Resident A why he took them, he explained that he wanted to
put them on in the shower because it made him feel like he was having kids with a
female peer on the unit.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
7

ANALYSIS: There is insufficient evidence to show that Mott Children’s
Residence failed to provide appropriate supervision for Resident
A. Mott Children’s Residence is a co-ed facility. The female
peer’s cubby, which Resident A had access to, is located on the
unit in a public area. It is possible that while Resident A was
sitting on the bench, which is located directly underneath the
cubbies, he took the female peer’s underwear unbeknownst to
the staff. The staff reported that the female peer is no longer
permitted to keep clothes in her cubby.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend no change in the
license status.
